root: ^Me：(Seanamae's studio looks awesome. How I'd love a studio of my own...)
^Me：(No wonder I'm just a self-proclaimed painter. There's nothing romantic about being penniless, once you look at it close enough.)
^Me：(Does Seanamae live in her studio, though? It's not the first time I'm here, but everything seem unfamiliar.)
^Me：(The draft!) You'll turn what I draw into a tattoo design?
^Seanamae：Sure, if a client likes it. I'll also make some tattoo stickers out of them for sale.
^Me：Sounds great. Is there any specific requirement for texture or material?
^Seanamae：I'm only using your draft as the basis for the final designs, so I'm cool with anything you feel like.

theme: ^Me：Cool. The theme would be, ugh, something about deep sea monsters, right?
^Seanamae：You do remember that I like to call this place "Institute of Fantastic Creatures."
^Seanamae: I work with monsters, exotic creatures, divine creatures, whether they are from ancient history books, rumors, or even comics.
^Me：(She is so obsessed with these legends. I could see it from her <color=green>hairband</color>. But isn't this...?)
theme_continue: ^Me：Sea slugs, jellyfish... Aren't these just ordinary marine animals? I thought you're only interested in legends.
^Seanamae：Everyone has their guilty pleasure. Mine is to connect fantasy with what's tangible, as if finding sources for the human imagination.
^Seanamae: A bit boring if I put it this way, isn't it?
^Me：Not at all. It's reasonable that you need something a sketching exercise. Before creating something convincingly imaginative, you need to find references first.
^Seanamae：Glad that you see it this way.
^Me：I'm curious, thought, do you actually believe in these mystical creatures?
^Seanamae：It's impossible--and also wrong, if I may add--to contain these mysterious beings in glass tanks like tourist attractions, but they could be concrete in some other ways.
^Seanamae: Physical locations where people could visit, like Lovecraft's grave at Providence? Stories of sightings, for us all to wonder?
^Seanamae: The allusion to them, which we dug out in history books; or the blurred shadows that look strangely familiar, which we spotted in old photos...
^Seanamae: These are the traces of their existence.
^Seanamae：You could dismiss them as myths, but you could also piece up the evidences that'd lead you to an "unpleasant" truth.
^Me：Wow. I didn't expect it to be so... serious.
^Seanamae：Of course it's serious! And sincere. I wouldn't say that to any customer of the shop, though.
^Seanamae：Hey, I've been talking so much today! It's rare that I became the client here. My customers usually do the talking.
^Seanamae：Perhaps painting is also a dangerous profession, don't you think?
^Seanamae：It's just like being a bartender. You'll have to be discrete...about all the frightening truths.
^Seanamae: To make it fair play, how about I tell you a secret?
^Seanamae：Haha, if you agree to tell me a secret in return.
danger: ^Me：Ugh………… (Please don't tell me you have a secret occupation.)
^Seanamae：Hey, relax. Forgot how paranoid you are. What about we call it a "fun fact?"
trace_scholar: ^Seanamae：So. Beyond being a tattoonist, I'm also an ichnologist.
^Me: Ichnology? Let me guess, it has something to do with traces.
^Seanamae: You guessed right. Ichno- is, indeed, the greek root for "trace." The subject was originally about traces left by evolution, like fossils of dinasour footprints.
^Seanamae: While displacement gained popularity, the discipline evolved to include traces let behind by displacement. Well, you can see it as an applied track.
^Me：Hmm. That sounds interesting, I've never heard of it before.
^Me：(I'm so glad she isn't an agent for BIA.)
^Me：(Painter, mathematician, now ichnologist... Aren't we birds of a feather.)
^Seanamae：Not at all practical, though. You couldn't really expect us help to with displacement accidents, or anything alike. It's all rather theoretical.
^Seanamae：It is our principle that everything leaves traces. We'd forget about them easily, yet it's precisely the effort it takes to trace them back that defines human agency.
^Seanamae：In addition to studying the carriers of traces - for example, the razor left in the bathroom after your husband disappeared - we also study the mechanisms of forgetting.
^Seanamae：The academia only officially recognized the Ichnology of Displacement a year ago, after Clara Tracé's article “On the Application of Ichnology to Reverse Displacement.”
^Seanamae: Before Tracé, everyone thought we were delusional.
^Seanamae：To finish this essay, Tracé displaced almost everything. It's said that she found everything back through traces. If it's real, it's a miricle.
^Seanamae：In fact, I just returned from a conference at the Geminipolis. It's the first time Ichnologists meet on the east coast.
^Seanamae：Oh, an interesting fact: Carpe Diem sponsored the event.
^Seanamae：Although we couldn't really trust the company, it's good that the industry's offering support. The capitalism found value in our work, evidently.
^Me：Is it like an interdisciplinary research for you, originating from the art of tattoo?
^Me：Like, if we see tattoo as some sort of a trace.
^Me：We often make them to conmemorate things that are important to us, that we'd have them engraved on our body, in case we forget.
^Seanamae：Exactly. Even if it's just a tattoo on impulse, you'd remember that chose to make it. Even when you'd forgotten all about why. That's how humans assign meaning.
^Seanamae：I had to complain, though, more people have been coming to me to cover their tattoos since displacement became popular.
^Seanamae：Could you have imagined? I've covered more tattoos of names than the names I actually know in life.
^Me：It's creepy to think that there are things, once so precious that you'd have it carved into your body, would someday cease to be meaningful.
^Seanamae：Only the traces left on the skin could remind you of a past you'd all forgotten.
^Me：It's my secret, in return for yours.
^Me：You asked in your postcard how you couldn't reach me. Yesterday, I was probably involved in a displacement accident.
^Me：I lost all my stuff, except for this fish scale. Don't ask me what it is.
^Seanamae：I never thought you'd become one of my potential clients. Hey, I understand you.
^Seanamae：What do you want from me, then?
^Seanamae：As the tattoonist, I could help you cover it. Forget about it altogether, even. As the ichnologist, though, I'd help you get to the bottom of it. So, what is your wish?
findOut: ^Me：I'd like to get to the bottom of it.
^Seanamae：This fish scale is, doubtless, the carrier of trace.
^Me：You'er the marine expert. Could you tell where it's from?
^Seanamae：Somehow, it feels familiar, although I'm sure I'd never seen anything like it before.
^Seanamae：Hey, don't get all worked up yet. Just a annoying feeling of familiarity.
^Seanamae：I think, its owner may have disappeared.
^Seanamae：From displacement, obviously, whatever fish it was.
cover: ^Me：At least I'd stop feeling like there's something lacking in my life.
^Seanamae：It'd be just some random fish scale after you displace it.
^Seanamae：Perhaps you'd be freed from the oblication, or angst, you're feeling right now.
^Seanamae：Sure, you'd feel that it's a bit of a shame. But it's not your fault that you just want to live on without the weight on your life.
^Me：Perhaps my talk about forgetting isn't really true.
^Me：Mermaids... I couldn't escape her. She'd come back in my dream.
^Me：Like an illusion, the ocean burnt in her eyes. Her tail gently sweeps across my fingertips. A miracle, a whisper, a lure.
^Me：Yet she blurred into the waves in an instance, exhausting my gaze...
^Me：Well, I feel the fish scale belongs to a mermaid.
^Seanamae：Tell me more about the mermaid part!
^Seanamae：Don't displace it, I beg you. At least wait till you tell me more about the mermaid.
mermaid: ^Me：I think, I guess, I don't know... Well, after I drank the water infused with this scale...don't ask me why! Anyways. I drew a mermaid.
^Me：Sure, I happened to have it with me.
^Seanamae：Well, how should I put it. It's beautiful in a surprising way.
^Me：Hey, stop the teasing. Can you think of something?
^Seanamae：Mermaid is one of the most welcomed fairytales about fantastic marine life.
^Seanamae：some believe that they are just dugongs with seaweed on their heads. There are so many rumors about them, even literature favors them.
^Seanamae：Speaking of which, there are mermaid wetsuits for sale in town.
^Seanamae：Mermaid are always the consumed. their bodies always labeled with beauty, obejct of desire, fragility, like foam. Sometimes even said to be used for refining oil and lighting lamps.
^Seanamae：Unfortunately, I don't remember this purple-haired mermaid. Perhaps, when modernity has us all, I am unable to imagine beyond the so-called “mermaid shows.”
^Seanamae：If they exist, I hope they're never found by humans.
^Me：You think I shouldn't look for her?
^Seanamae：Hmm, is she just a mermaid to you?
^Seanamae：You can have the painting back. Sorry, I've not been of much help.
^Seanamae：It's a great draft for tattoos, though.
^Me：Thanks. But I deteste the idea of her being tattooed onto someone else.
^Seanamae：Ahh, I see. Definitely not just a mermaid, then.
^Seanamae：I'm not messing. It's an important lead. Trace.
^Seanamae：Physical disappearance is always accompanied by oblivion.
^Seanamae：Oblivion is a complex matter. While everyone would lose the memory of the disappeared object, it is also very personal.
^Seanamae：You could forget about one specific fish, but you couldn't forget the category of fish, as long as there's still fish left.
^Seanamae：Good questions. It makes me wonder if something similar had already happened.
^Seanamae：Perhaps there's always more to the world that we just can't remember.
^Seanamae：Perhaps mermaids'd gone extinct, and you were doomed with the destiny of finding the last of them?
^Seanamae：It's not it, then. Back to the specific fish, though, for everyone who'd came into contact with it, they'd forget different things about it.
^Seanamae：To continue with life, we justify ourselves.
^Seanamae：You would justify the disappearance of the fish as, for instance, you didn't own fish in the first place.
^Seanamae: While the one who sold you the fish would justify their memory, that you bought another fish.
^Seanamae：Perhaps you're more resistant to self-justification by nature. Therefore you can't just choose to forget.
^Seanamae：It is also true that we all feel, to different degrees, nolstalgic about the things we lost.
^Seanamae：It's hard to trace exactly who experiences the disappearance of a loved one, but cases of depression are increasing since the displacement occurred.
^Seanamae: People often feel unexplained grief, most likely caused by the sense of absence that comes with displacement.
^Seanamae：Therefore, feelings--depression, possessiveness, no matter how it occurs--are also traces to the "placeholders."
^Seanamae：We're all somewhat self-centered, that we only perceive things in relation to ourselves.
^Seanamae：If you had a child who disappeared, you'd maintain the habit of care-taking even when you'd forgotten all about the child.
^Seanamae：Perhaps you would get a pet instead.
^Seanamae：This behavior of finding substitutions, or "placeholders," helps with the illusion that nothing had changed. Eases the anxiety.
^Seanamae：Back to the mermaid. Perhaps the reason for your possessiveness of this fish scale...
^Me：Is that there's a placeholder for a mermaid, somewhere in my mind.
^Seanamae：These are, in fact, the hypothesis I raised in my first ichnology essay. It didn't get published because I used words like "emotion" and "attitude" without clear definition.
^Seanamae：Don't take it too seriously, but I wonder, what kind of a placeholder is this mermaid to you?
object: ^Me：Well, I'm not even sure it's a person.
^Me：Although I'm inclined to believe that she might've been human.
^Me：That I've lost in a displacement accident.
^Me：That really isn't important in itself. Perhaps I just don't like things to change.
^Me：Would that be less interesting for you? If it's just an object?
^Seanamae：Not at all. The opportunity to reverse displacement? I could make it my PhD thesis.
lover: ^Me：Sorry. It's pathetic. How I rambled, like some alchoholic asshole who talks nonsense about being penniless and non-stop about the ex. Or something.
^Seanamae：No one thought so until you said it.
^Seanamae：* sign * No, painter. I'd rather you're just the regular alchoholic.
^Me：(Did I really lost a loved-one to the void?)
^Me：(I should probalbly be in pain, but the only thing I'm feeling now is confusion.)
^Me：Do you think there's anyway I could get her back?
nightmare: ^Me：To be honest, I'm a bit scared of her somehow.
^Me：I don't care about the things I lost. I'd live. I could draw with found objects. But the mermaid...
^Me：As if I just can't go on without figuring out her myth.
^Me：I hate it. But I also can't let go.
^Seanamae：You want to free the mermaid, before you free yourself.
^Me：You're making her sound like some earth-bound spirit.
^Seanamae：The void could've been the same place as the underworld.
^Me：Darn, Seanamae, your research on mystical creatures is going a bit too diversed.
^Me：Seriously. If she really is an earth-bound spirit, how could I set her free?
canI: ^Seanamae：I don't know, but I have faith in you. After all, you're the painter.
^Seanamae：Painters scan life. Painters create the impossible. Painters visualize beyond imagination.
^Seanamae：Painters gave birth to the legends that I'm so passionate about.
^Me：Hey, stop it, you're making me shy. Besides, aren't you also an artist?
^Seanamae：I won't consider myself as an artist, really, because I only recreate what's already here.
^Me：You'll be so disappointed in me when you see the draft.
^Seanamae：Let me see. Okay. So is this...
^Me：Uh. It's the tail. Please, take another look after I finish...
^Seanamae：I'm gonna make some tea, feel free to take your time.
^Seanamae：By the way, you can take a look at the book shelf. For inspiration.
^Me：(Seanamae has quite a collection of books. Which one should I flip through?)
monster_book: ^Me：(Which one should I look at first?)
8_2_monster: ^: Looks like a goat, with two horns and wings on its back. The second of the seven brothers, closely tied to his compatriots.
^: Disappears every Monday. Constantly disappearing and reappearing.
^: Born with his brothers in a high fever, vaporizing his mother's body before birth, the embryo still unbroken.
^: was partaken of by six brothers on the first day, and was reanimated by re-conception on the second day;
^：the second brother was partaken of on the second day, and was reanimated on the third day;
^：the third brother was partaken of on the third day, and was reanimated on the fourth day......
^: After seven days, all the brothers experienced death and rebirth before being born from the embryo.
^：Since then, the seven brothers have disappeared into the world one day a week.
^Me: (What a story...... Why does it sound a bit familiar?)
chai_monster: ^: A monster under the waters of the deep sea with an unlimited appetite but no digestion.
^：She ate too much and she vomite. She vomite. She vomite. She vomite.
^: She ate the sea and land. She vomited and made them meaningless garbage.
^: She was crushed and chained to the bottom of the ocean, until her swollen body was transformed. She seduced her guards, and subsequently ate them.
^: She went ashore and went cruising on land every day, tempting people into the water with her body. But she must return to the depth every evening.
xstar_monster: ^: Has many faces, never shows its true face.
^: Herbivorous, with an unusual appetite for struggle, and the ability to “hunt.”
^：He doesn't kill or eat his prey, but only plays with them, removing parts of them as trophies and mounting them on himself.
^：Always happy. The Beast, a symbol of energy and hope, is an omen of good fortune.
^：A man once dreamed of seeing its true face, so he became its attendant.
^：He told his friends, "I will take off his mask at night!"
^：The next day, the attendant appeared. The friend asked the attendant, "What does he look like?"
^：The attendant said, “It is what it is."
^：On the third day, the friend's wife fled from the room in a panic, and asked everyone where her husband was, and everyone wondered, isn't he right beside you?
^I: (So what happened to the attendant and the friend? Eh, a beast of good omen?)

trace_essay: ^Me: (Actually, I'm quite interested in ichnology. Let's have a challenge!)
^: ...... Difficulties in ichnology have long been recognized as stemming from the uncontrollable nature of samples.

^: “Traces” themselves are an anchor for the physical study of memory, but their credible authentication can only be traced back to a section of the Code for the Authentication of the Replacement of Individual Ownership (henceforth: DP-3x3).
^: According to the DP-3x3 criterion, certification of the validity of traces requires the corroboration of the collective memory of three moments and three or more people.
^: In the post-replacement era, the loss of memory has been relegated to force majeure.
^：Samples of memory lack the most basic stability required for experimentation, and certification of compliance with the standard is very difficult to obtain.
^: Even the data of DP-3x3 is suspected of being falsified due to its widespread use in the determination of property disputes among the population.
^: While materialized memories require traces as anchors, the authentication of traces requires DP-3x3 records that are almost impossible to obtain.
^：This phenomenon is a reflection of the recursive difficulties of trace research.
^: We need to develop a whole new standard, a more flexible, bold, and imaginative norm; one that goes beyond the old scientific foundations of quantitative research.
^: We need more stories, drawings, art, sounds; we need to understand traces and memory in a whole new dimension......
^Me: (...... I don't seem to be as interested as I think I am.)

haiming_back_personal: ^Me：(Don't let her catch me going through her diary, Oops, where did I take it from...)
^Me：I'm so sorry! I just liked the cover... Okay I admit I did flip through a few pages...
^Seanamae：Maybe it's not such a bad thing to have one's past known? I keep my notebook with my other books, maybe waiting for the day when they'll be read.

^Seanamae：By the way, is this jacket yours?
